Award.AwardTitle: OP: Plasmonic Enhancement of Chiral Forces for Enantiomer Separation
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Bjoern Reinhard of Boston University is developing a new approach to use light to sort chemical molecules based on their "handedness." Similar to the left and right human hand, chemical molecules can exist in different forms that cannot be superimposed. The term for this categorization is called "chirality." Because molecules with different chirality can show very different chemical and pharmacological behaviors it is often important to separate them. To achieve this goal, nanoscale antennas are being developed that, upon radiation with light, generate forces that point in different directions for molecules with different handedness. An outreach program developed by Professor Reinhard offers undergraduate students and inner city high school students opportunities to participate in this research program and to learn more about how light interacts with molecules. The broader impacts of this work include the development of universal chemical separation techniques that are applicable to a broad range of molecules and that can make pharmaceutical compounds safer and cheaper.

Professor Reinhard is developing plasmonic antennas that provide strong enough gradients in optical chirality density to enable enantiomer-selective optical forces. The project addresses the design criteria of nanoantennas that generate enantio-selective forces in evanescent enhanced chiral fields of uniform sign. These structures are implemented and characterized, and their ability to separate enantiomers is tested experimentally. Throughout the project both simulations and experiments are applied to optimize plasmonic antennas and maximize chiral forces. This approach will lead to a quantitative understanding of how chiral light-matter interactions are enhanced by resonant plasmonic nanostructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chiral molecules exist in two structures, so called enantiomers, which are mirror images of each other that cannot be superimposed on each other. Electromagnetic fields can also be chiral but the interactions between chiral molecules and electromagnetic fields are weak and there is a need for adequate antenna designs that can enhance chiral light-matter interactions. This project has developed new nanoantenna designs and materials to enhance key properties that determine chiral light-matter interactions: optical chirality density and its gradient. Dimers of nanofibers and nanowires as well as dimers of high refractive index nanoparticles and noble metal (gold) nanoparticles were identified to generate same-sign optically chirality density that greatly exceeds that of circularly polarized light. One fundamental challenge in the design of optical antennas that can separate chiral molecules based on their interactions with chiral light fields is the fact that optical gradient forces, which are not enantiomer selective, are usually much stronger in the vicinity of the nanoantenna. In the case of optical nanowire dimers, a new design concept was introduced to spatially separate the maxima of optical gradient forces and chiral optical forces, paving the path to the next generation of nanophotonic antennas for enantiomer-selective trapping and separation.

Intellectual Merit: New antenna designs for enhancing chiral light-matter interactions and chiral force generation were developed and analyzed with an emphasis on antenna designs that are by themselves structurally achiral. The fundamental electromagnetic working principles underlying optical chirality density generation in these achiral antenna structures were elucidated. Electromagnetic materials generated from high refractive index dielectric building blocks as well as from different plasmonic building blocks, including gold nanoparticles and doped metal oxide nanocrystals, were investigated in order to generate a spectral response from the visible to the infrared region of the spectrum. 

Broader impact: The development of new nanoantenna concepts for enhancing chiral light-matter interactions is important for developing improved spectral characterization modalities for chiral molecules, for enantiomer-selective separation strategies, and for controlling enantiomer-selective chemical reactivity. In addition to its scientific impact, the project also had significant outreach components. The Reinhard Laboratory held two-day Nano-Workshops in which high school teachers and undergraduate students not affiliated with Boston University obtained training in nanoparticle synthesis and characterization as well as in the theory underlying plasmonically enhanced light-matter interactions. Furthermore, the project had important educational components. The project formed the basis for two PhD theses.
